revision.text: {{also|Xīnhuá|xīnhuā}} ==English== {{wikipedia}} {{commonscat|Xinhua County}} ===Alternative forms=== * {{q|from [[Wade–Giles]]}} {{l|en|Hsinhua}}, {{l|en|Hsin-hua}} * {{q|from [[Tongyong Pinyin]]}} {{l|en|Sinhua}} ===Pronunciation=== {{rfp|en}} ===Etymology 1=== From the {{bor|en|cmn-pinyin|-}} romanization of {{bor|en|cmn|-}} {{zh-l|新華|lit=New China}}. ====Proper noun==== {{en-proper noun}} # {{place|en|district|prefecture-level city/Shijiazhuang|province/Hebei|c/China}}. #* {{quote-journal |en |date=July 19, 2002 |author=Tao Yuan |author2=Chen Ying |title=Business Booster or Big Brother? |journal={{w|Beijing Today}} |url=https://archive.org/details/BeijingTodayCN20020719/ |issue=62 |issn=2095-9591 |oclc=958634538 |section=Voice {{lang|zh|声音}} |page=6 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/BeijingTodayCN20020719/page/n5/ |column=1 |text=In a move hailed by some as a step towards promoting business morality and branded as basically Orwellian by others, the country’s first community credit and reputation file system was launched in the '''Xinhua''' district of Shijiazhuang, Hebei province, on March 20, according to a report run in ''China Youth Daily'' June 9.}} # {{place|en|district|prefecture-level city/Pingdingshan|province/Henan|c/China}}. # {{place|en|town|forestry district/Shennongjia|p/Hubei|c/China}}. # [[XNA]]; {{ellipsis of|en|Xinhua [[news agency|News Agency]]|gloss=新华社}}, the {{w|lang=en|New China News Agency}} {{gloss|新华通讯社}}. The government news agency of the [[People's Republic of China]]. #* {{quote-journal |en |date=December 3, 1978 |title=CHINA HUATCHERS KEEP EYE ON BEIJING IN '79 |journal=The Daily Colonist |url=https://archive.org/details/dailycolonist19781203/ |location=[[Victoria]], [[British Columbia]] |volume=120 |issue=292 |issn=0839-4261 |oclc=1115071851 |page=1 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/dailycolonist19781203/ |column=6 |text=China's official news agency said Saturday it will adopt the Chinese Pinyin phonetic alphabet beginning Jan. 1, when Peking will become Beijing (pronounced ''bay-jing'') and the agency '''Xinhua''' instead of Hsinhua.}} #* {{quote-journal |en |date=April 19, 1981 |title=Yeh, Teng far apart |journal=Free China Weekly |url=https://archive.org/details/sim_free-china-weekly_1981-04-19_22_15/ |volume=XXII |issue=15 |location=[[Taipei]] |issn=0016-0318 |oclc=1786626 |page=3 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/sim_free-china-weekly_1981-04-19_22_15/page/n2/ |text=The “'''Hsinhua''' News Agency,” in a wire report from Canton, said that “Yeh Chien-ying, accompanied by Wang Cheng, member of the politburo, has visited Chuhai and other places in Kwangtung province.” |brackets=on}} =====Translations===== {{trans-top|district; town in central China}} * Chinese: *: Mandarin: {{t+|cmn|新華|sc=Hani}}, {{t+|cmn|新华|tr=Xīnhuá|sc=Hani}} {{trans-mid}} * Japanese: {{t-needed|ja}} {{trans-bottom}} ===Etymology 2=== From the {{bor|en|cmn-pinyin|-}} romanization of {{bor|en|cmn|-}} {{zh-l|新化}}. ====Proper noun==== {{en-proper noun}} # {{place|en|county|prefecture-level city/Loudi|p/Hunan|c/China}} # {{alternative form of|en|Sinhua}} ([[Taiwan]]) #* {{quote-book |en |year=2014 |last=Crook |first=Steven |chapter=A Forgotten Tribe Campaigns for Recognition |title=Taiwan |url=https://archive.org/details/taiwan0000croo/ |edition=2nd |series={{w|Bradt Guides}} |ISBN=978 1 84162 497 6 |OCLC=913850406 |page=223 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/taiwan0000croo/page/223/ |text=On the face of it, Tainan is ethnically homogeneous. Almost everyone, it seems, is descended from Han Chinese who came to Taiwan two or more centuries ago. That's what most people believe, anyhow. The leaders of the '''Xinhua'''-based Siraya Culture Association think otherwise, arguing that many Tainan folk are indigenous even if they don't know it.[...]You won't hear Siraya spoken in '''Xinhua''', but here are a few words to impress - or baffle - the locals: ''tabe'' is hello; ''tatalag'' means welcome; ''alid'' means god, while ''alilid'' means to thank.}} #* {{quote-web |en |date=2017/07/30 |last=Crook |first=Steven |title=Handling Snakes and other Nocturnal Adventures in Taiwan’s Forests |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170730023123/https://international.thenewslens.com/article/74309 |archivedate=30 July 2017 |work={{w|The News Lens}} |section=Lifestyle |text=Harris grew up in Florida. “There were always snakes around, and I was always very interested in them,” he says. Seeing any snake in Florida was noteworthy, he remembers, but when he goes out herping in the woodlands of Tainan City’s '''Xinhua''' District, “with a decent flashlight, you might see a dozen individuals of seven different species. And more than half of them would be venomous.”}} #* {{quote-web |en |date=2021/08/24 |last=Liao |first=George |title=Fruit and vegetable market in southern Taiwan expected to attract tourists |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20210825135453/https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/4275931 |archivedate=25 August 2021 |work={{w|Taiwan News}} |text=The Tainan City Government is banking on a nearly completed fruit and vegetable market in '''Xinhua''' District becoming not only a comfortable environment for shopping but also a tourist magnet.}} #* {{seemoreCites|en}} =====Translations===== {{trans-top|county}} * Chinese: *: Mandarin: {{t+|cmn|新化|tr=Xīnhuà|sc=Hani}} {{trans-mid}} * Japanese: {{t-needed|ja}} {{trans-bottom}} {{trans-see|Sinhua}}
